CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporter.

Insect Powder at Clark's Drug Store.
Sheriff Haggard returned from Banche on Monday.
No rifle practice on Wednesday owing to rain.
Bargains at Wigmore this month.
Prices away.
Cherry imported Havana Cigars at Clark's Drug Store.
Mr. J.A. Bradtman has purchased the lot east of Stewart & McLeod's, on which he proposes to build a house.
Mr. J.J. Campbell returned from Carrot River district on Saturday last. He reports the crops looking well.
Mr. F. Fulton has returned from Fort Qu'Appelle, where he was on Kinneir's farm, near that of H. Clark, on which he intends to build a hotel.
Mr. H. Doull, travelling in the district, reports a good crop of wheat in the districts of Hamilton and Wainpeg, is in town.
The steamer Northward arrived on Saturday from the forks of the river and on Sunday left for Battleford and Edmonton.
The time limiters across the river have been removed from Chicago and commenced operation a short distance down the river at Belleville.
The school house cannot be completed so soon as there is no place to open school until the new building is finished.
Sgt. Perry, of the N.W.M. Police, and Mrs. Perry, who went east some years ago, returned last Monday.
Egyptian Rhomatic Oil, an invaluable remedy for every kind of pain, at Clark's Drug Store.
Mr. A.W. R. Markley, Inspector for the Confederation Life Insurance Company, has been here for several days, but after an extended trip through the Territories.
Mr. Chas. Main returned on Sunday from Winnipeg, where he had been to see his eldest daughter who was on her way to England, where she had been spending a year.
The vote will be taken again on Tuesday next for the purpose of electing a member of the Territorial Council.
It is the duty of every one to vote "yes."
The voters list for 1887 has been compiled and may be seen in the office of the Editor.
One day last week a smoke was seen rising from one of our dwellings, we thought it was a fire, but on examination it was found that the driver carried a smudge with him.
The Hon. L. Clarke returned from Carlton on Monday, where he had been to meet Mr. Wright, Chief Commissioner of Indian Affairs, and also visiting the various posts to the north and west to Winnipeg.
Mr. J. Williams, party that they have everything ready now to proceed with the work of removing the trees which are now blocking the river.
During the river being very high they can only work on the sides of the road, but when the water goes down they can perform their task.
It destroys flora, bogs upon plants, mosquitoes, flies and other pests, and a host of other pests.
No housekeeper should be without it.
No housekeeper should be without it.
The town fathers are the people to look after the matters.
Mr. A.B. Dodge, a cove store, at Clark's Drug Store.
Last Thursday evening the P.A.C. met at Clark's Drug Store.
The confidence of our neighbor was well shown by his Parliamentary duties at Ottawa.
Mr. Macdonald visited the town and delivered a speech, and a good time was spent in music and speech making.
On Saturday evening the ladies met at Clark's Drug Store and were also presented with a contribution towards defraying expenses.
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW,
PUBLISHED BY
J. D. MAVEETY

This Paper is Supplemented by the following:
NEW YORK.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 5, 1887.

"GIVE me the liberty to know, to utter, and to argue freely, all matters of concern to the public; to read books where I please, to speak my sentiments in public, and to choose my own teachers, and not the teachers of the State."

In his day there was indeed little real freedom of any kind, and the liberty which he then held dear was but an aspiration, to all appearances of the most remote attainment. It has been reserved for our day and for our generation to obtain an amount of liberty of mind and action, notably in this respect, to which our own ancestors were strangers and which even the present generation in most foreign countries has never to this day enjoyed. We can easily imagine what intelligent foreigners, European continentalists for instance, must think when they become first acquainted with the perfect freedom and independence of thought and action which our newspapers discuss so merrily and vital questions, cut and slash public measures and scarcely prominent men without mercy.

Our Dominion press also takes full advantage of the peculiar liberty it enjoys. Loyalists may do so and may such liberty never degenerate into license. We must say, however, we like not the airy carelessness with which some of our contemporaries indulge in comparisons on the comparative merits of the British connection and we are greatly mistaken if the thoughtful reading public enjoy the numberless declamations of dreary outrage which a portion of the Canadian press continues pouring over the land on the unalloyed benefits of commercial union and those journals on the enlightened evils of centralisation, the dark ill-success of the Confederation and the sins and shortcomings of our rulers in gross and in detail, in which poor pessimists virtually tell us our country is going to the dogs.

Two or three times it might have been supposed from reading the same newspapers that all possible and impossible grievances whatever were located in the North-West Territories, that we were exposed to hardships and moreover that though we wanted everything we could do nothing for ourselves, that we were, generally speaking, a poor ungrateful set. But patience, as the proverb says, is the longest of the noble heritage nor the distinguishing feature of the North-West. We seem to be now tolerably happy and contented in our position and prospects. It appears that many of the older provinces feel themselves down trodden and ill-used and misgoverned. Is it they whom blind guides and interested men have led astray? Or is it hard to be happy by first showing them their misery and their folly. But they will survive the process and see through it all in time.

We observe there is an Inter-Provincial Congress in course of organization. It will probably act as a safety valve to blow off pent-up and superfluous energy and we may hope it will discover a perfect panacea for all ills. Possibly croakers may however be told beforehand that there is no patriotism in belittling their country—that many sound judges of the same country are convinced on quite identical terms that considering the bad times prevailing all over the world, Canada has had good reason to congratulate itself on her prosperity. But who wants now is some thing alone. We may do worse than possess our souls in patience for a time and re-pose some confidence in the rulers who have so recently replaced ours.

The population of the North-West Territories bids fair to become by and by as considerable in its character as the United States.

Not to speak of the English and French speaking Canadians, who may almost be reckoned indigenous, we are constantly receiving recruits from the old countries to make up the United Kingdom as well as most of the other European nationalities. The Scandinavian element is becoming fully represented as well by natives born Studies, Norwegians, Danes, Swedes, Finns, etc., who relatives the Icelanders. The latter in particular have been arriving in large numbers and the cry is still that they come. It appears that the Icelandic exodus were about to take place from their interesting but barren island. It is reported that late the population of Iceland has been suffering severely from bad harvests and that many of the more westerly would gladly leave for the Canadian North West were means to enable them to do so forthcoming, which will eventually be provided.

After these volcanic rocks and in homely soil such communities must seem an earthly paradise, and there is room and to spare for them all, if they choose to come. These Icelanders will without doubt make excellent settlers. They travelled in the island representing the people as industrious, peaceful and religious. Considering their isolation and by no means affluent circumstances, they are also comparatively well educated and having been nurtured to hardships from birth they will be able to make light of such little asperities as all must at first expect who embrace the healthful and invigorating life of Canadian pioneers.

QU'APPELLE

From the Progress, July 21.

The Progress presents from upas a new addition to Qu'Appelle street. There was a shower of rain passed over here yesterday, it was badly needed. Much needed.

An immense number of agricultural implements have been sold here this year, and many of them going to Prince Albert. The farmers have been anticipating a good harvest.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

REGINA.

From the Leader July 19.

Inspector Morris, W.M.P., leaves today for his post at Battleford.

Commissioner Hetherington went to Calgary Friday last.

Several tea trains passed Regina during the week.

Col. Goddard, agent of the British Government, left on Tuesday last for the west.

Mr. P. M. Barker has returned to the capital after having visited the registry offices throughout the Territories.

Tuesday last was a very fine day at Pi-a-pot's Reserve. The occasion was celebrated by a dog feast and medicine dance.

A bunch of hay over six feet in length was brought in from Lake Lake last week. It is expected to last so long that the reserve frequently lose their cattle among it.

Supt. Cotterill, W.M.P., has been away from Regina for a few days on his return from the east. He has been to Medicine Hat Tuesday with Insp. Bruce. He is now back to take charge of the post at Battleford.

Medals on account of the late North West Rebellion, will be delivered by the Mounted Police next month.

A man was arrested last night on the information last by the Mounted Police caught on Pi-a-pot's reserve with whisky in his possession, doubtless to sell to the Indians.

LETHBRIDGE.

From the News July 20.

A heavy freight of goods arrived here last week. It is the N.W.M.P. Police, Fort MacLeod.

Haying is being commenced in this district. It is expected the crop will be a good one this year.

A shower of rain last week would be of great benefit to the country, as things are beginning to get pretty dry.

We had a pretty sharp frost here last night, although it had been very much damp, still several of the tender vegetables were nipped.

NEILSON & McBEATH
WIMBLEDON

London, July 14.—There was again today a very large attendance at Wim-
bledon, and intense interest was taken in
the shooting for the Queen's prize. On
the first day the second and third ranges of
the first stage were fired by nearly all the,
firing being at 500 and 600 yards, and
scores of 200 points being secured by
many competitors. Private Gillies, of the
90th battalion, of Winnipeg, leads the Cana-
dian contingent, having scored 300 points
against all competitors, his score being
61. It is impossible to give his exact
place, owing to the non-completion of
scores by a number of competitors.

In the Heath competition for prizes amounting to £115, two shots at 500
yards, six shots at 600 yards, and three
shots, C. N. Mitchell, of the 90th,
Winnipeg, leads with a score of 300
points. In the Albrecht competition, seven
shots at each, 500 or 600 yards,
prices £5 each, prizes were secured, after
scores were keenly contested by Private
Gillies, of the 90th, Prince Edward Island,
and Lieut. Cartwright, of the 47th, who
have taken money prizes in every case.

In the Alfred competition, £200, seven
shots, Lieut. Cartwright captured prizes.

July 15.—At Wimbledon today to-day
the firing at the third or 600 yards' range of
the first stage of the Queen's prize was
completed. The highest possible number
of points at the three ranges of this stage
is 180. The highest English score is 160.
The Canadian scores are as follows: 160,
200, and 600 yards, seven shots at each.
Quarter-Master Sergeant Ogg, Corporal
Langstroth, Lieut. Mitchell, Pte. Gillies,
90th Winnipeg, 90th, Lieut. W. Mitchell,
22nd Bruno, 80, Sergeant A. Thompson,
Vellore, Rifle company, 80, Corporal
Langstroth, East Durham, 80, Corporal
Langstroth, 3rd Cavalry, New Bena-
vis, 80, Corp. W. Taylor, Fort Hamilton,
St. Paul, 80, Corporal J. Smith, South
Road, 81; Pte. H. Morris, 12th Hamilton,
St. Paul, 80, Lieut. W. H., P. W. O. R.,
Kingston, 80, Corporal J. Smith, 80;
Sergt. W. C. King, 45th, West Dur-
ham, 78; Pte. Logan, 13th, Hamilton,
77; Sergt. Logan, 13th, Hamilton,
76; Sergt. Logan, 13th, Hamilton,
76; Lieut. E. A. Smith, St. John, N.B.,
rifle company, 73; Lieut. D. H. Cooper,
80, Lieut. J. M. Cooper, 80, Corporal
P. F. L. L., 65; Sergt. C. N. Mitchell,
90th, Winnipeg, 61.

July 16.—Today shooting for the
Queen's prize advances the interest natu-
rally increases, and as the number of
competitors grows larger, the more varied
results are more appreciated by the
spectators. Corp. Taylor, Pte. Morris
and Pte. Kanaley have taken many
more shots than any other competitor.

In the Daily Telegraph prize,
£300, seven shots at 500 yards, highest
possible score 35; Pte. Graham and Pte.
Kembery took 161; Pte. Graham won £2
each.

In the Prince of Wales' prize, £200,
seven shots at 200, and fifteen shots at
600 yards, the first stage was completed
by the highest possible score 230.
Pte. Kembery took 161; Pte. Graham
and Pte. Morris, 20.

July 17.—Being a general
half holiday here, the attendance at
Wimbledon was considerably augmented
and the interest shown by the various
sections was greatly increased. In the
Prince of Wales' prize, the highest pos-
sible score was Private Gillies of the 90th
battalion, Winnipeg, and Lieut. Cart-
wright, each scoring 97 points. Private
Gillies especially won, thus securing the
prize. Corporal Langstroth, Lieut. Mitchell,
of Hamilton, having been too
late, he takes £100 and badge.

The second stage of the Queen's com-
petition was completed yesterday, ten
shots 500 yards, and fifteen shots at 600
yards, highest possible score 125,
with the same of the first stage, making
the highest possible score 230. The
following are the leading men: Quarter-
Master Sergeant Ogg, 180, Corporal
Langstroth, 180, Sergt. Thompson, 187,
Pte. Graham, 180, Sergt. C. N. Mitchell,
179, Ogg, Langstroth, Thompson, Mitchell
are amongst the hundred men who will
be invited to the second and final stage at
500 and 600 yards.

In the Daily Telegraph prize, £300,
seven shots at 500 yards, Sergt. C. N.
Mitchell took 161.

In Tyne, £185, in connection with the
next stage Queen's prize, Pte. Gillies re-
ceived £100, Corporal Langstroth, Sergt.
Langstroth and Pte. Kanaley have each won a smaller sum.

July 20.—At Wimbledon shooting con-
tinued, Corporal Langstroth, English
marksmen, won the prize, scoring 710
points, Canada won second place, making 668
points, and third prize £100.

Much interest is exhibited today at
the final firing for Queen's prize.

The following are the winners: Warrant
Officer Middleton, with 274 points out of a
possible 280, Corporal Langstroth, of
Hamilton, 260, Sergt. Mitchell, New
Brunswick, 210, Lieut. Mitchell, 200
with 200 points. He receives £15.
Quarter-Master Sergt. Ogg, of Gosport
Rifle Battery, who has already booked
like a winner, scores 252, and received
£12. Sergt. Thomson, Victoria Rifles,
scores 220, and also Corporal Langstroth,
Sergt. Ogg and Sergt. Thomson have taken money prizes in every case.

The Duke of Cambridge visited the
Canadian camp today, where he was re-
ceived by Lord Montgomery, Col. Officer
of the Canadian camp, Lieut. Col. Macdonald,
John rifle company. His Royal High-
ness shook hands with Col. Officer and
Lieut. Col. Macdonald, and specially referred to
the capitulation of Pic. Gillies. Addressing
the volunteers, he said he had great
pleasure in visiting the camp, and that
he trusted they would take back
with them the best remembrances of what
they had witnessed there. He
spoke with satisfaction of the jubilee
celebrations and loyalty of the
Canadians. Later in the
day the Canadian Camp was visited by
the Prince of Wales, who shook hands
with Lieut. Col. Macdonald, and also
visited Pic. Gillies, on whose behalf
he pinned the badge he had won in the
Queen's prize. Afterward Lieut. Col.
Pic. Gillies and Lieut. Mitchell after-
wards walked with the Prince.

The Corporal Langstroth contest
continues today. Following are the
successful Canadians with their
highest possible scores: Sergt. Ogg,
180; Lieut. Cartwright, 180; Sergt.
Smith, 175; Lieut. Horn, 80; Sergt.
Mitchell, 90; Corporal Langstroth, 82;
Pte. Graham, 80; Pte. Ridley, 80;
Kanaley, 80.

EXHIBITION.

Price List of the Central River Agricultural Society's Second Annual Show held at Stanhope, Thursday, Sept. 18th, 1867.

Class II — Agricultural and general purpose horses—Fair in harness, 1st, £1; 2nd, 50c.

Class III — Heavy draught—Pair in harness, 1st, £1; 2nd, 50c.

Class IV — Native horses, pair in harness, 1st, £1; 2nd, 50c.

All teams in above classes to be attached to vehicles.

Class V — Horses and mares—Sec. 1, heavy draught, 1st, £1; 2nd, 50c.; Sec. 2, general purpose, 1st, £1; 2nd, 50c.; Sec. 3, native, 1st, £1; 2nd, 50c.

Special by the Secretary-Treasurer, one choice to the exhibitor who secures most first prizes.

ABRAHAM CONNER,
Secretary-Treasurer.

TOWN COUNCIL.

A regular meeting of the Council was held on Monday evening last. All the members present except Mayor Robertson. Mr. Bain was appointed chairman. The minutes of last meeting read and adopted.

APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES.

Applications for licenses have been received from Robertson & Pembroke for livery and feed stable; from Chas. Woodman for saloon; from Chas. Woodman & Co. for saloon; from Mr. Smith for saloon; from Theroux and Wm. Dilworth for dray; from Wm. Dilworth for dray; from Robert Buckley for saloon. All were granted.

ACCOUNTS.

Accounts were received from John McCallum, for the Town Council chamber, and from Wm. Dilworth for removing nineteen $18, filling holes in streets, $30; digging ditches $18; two nights service $6; election day $3. Referred to Finance Committee.

The treasurer presented his report for the month of July, showing a balance on hand of $100.

FINANCE AND ASSESSMENT.

The Chairman of the Finance and Assessment Committee recommended the following rates of assessment, viz.: R.J. Cass $10.25, Chas. Woodman $2.05.

The following by ballot received three readings and were ordered to be signed, sealed and returned. For the impounding of dogs, an assessment of twenty-five cents for municipal purposes; for authorizing an assessment for school purposes, forty cents per hundred feet of River street on river lot 68 and close part of Producer Avenue. The Council adjourned to meet on Monday, 15th inst., at 7 p.m.
